```{r, echo = FALSE, results = "hide"}
f1 <- sample(1:20, 1)
fnet <- f1 + sample(1:10, 1)
ans <- signif(sqrt(fnet^2 - f1^2), 3)

distractors <- c(fnet - f1, f1 + fnet)
sc <- num_to_schoice(ans, wrong = distractors, delta = ans/10, format = FALSE)
sc$questions <- sprintf("%.1f N", sc$questions)
```

Question
========
Carly pulls on a box with `r fmt(f1, 1)` N of force. Debby pulls on the the same box
at a right angle to Carly. How hard must Debby pull to make the resultant force
on the box `r fmt(fnet, 1)` N?

```{r, echo = FALSE, results = "asis"}
answerlist(sc$questions, markup = "markdown")
```


Solution
========
Perpendicular forces are related by the Pythagorean theorem.
$$F_{Debby} = \sqrt{F_{net}^2 - F_{Carly}^2} = \sqrt{(`r fnet` N)^2 - (`r f1` N)^2} = `r ans` \text{ N}$$
